awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Translation Strategies for Mutual Symbiosis in STS-Engineering Collaborations
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

The goal of this dissertation project will investigate how researchers in the field of Science and Technology Studies (STS) can work with other stakeholder groups to design and build technological artifacts. The core research question addresses how social scientists work collaboratively and productively with engineers, designers, business owners, and potential end users to produce usable technological artifacts. To address that question, the investigator will conduct a case study of the development and production of an open-source condom vending machine in Kumasi, Ghana. The investigator will use a mix of methods that includes critical making (activities that bridge the gap between critical thinking and physical making), interviews, design workshops, and collaborative documentation. The project has significant potential for making recommendations to designers, and to African health advocacy organizations.

Technical Summary 

STS is moving from its prior status as a technology critic to a more engaged collaborative role. The most successful of these collaborations have been in the area of lay participation, and new extensions have offered emphasis on promoting the legitimacy of lay-citizen perspectives. Important as this approach has been, restricting the role of STS researcher to that of a facilitator who brings lay citizens together with professionals often results in a very narrow deployment of the wide array of possible STS analytic insights and concepts. More direct forms of engagement with varying sets of stakeholders have been developed that include up-streaming, mid-streaming, anticipatory governance, and critical making. Inspired by this new body of work, the project will seek to extend and enhance the collaborative framework in the context of a specific case study, the development of a condom vending machine in the West African nation of Ghana. The investigator will develop an experimental foundation that offers a two-way symbiosis between STS researchers and engineers that will be conducive to long-term, project-based engineering and design interventions.

Over the life of the award, from February 2015 until February 2017, this DDRIG resulted in several activities performed by Co-PI David Banks and his collaborators. At the time of application about half of the awarded money was to go toward co-PI’s travel expenses but an institution-wide travel ban to Ghana (due to neighboring countries’ Ebola epidemic) prevented travel for most the life of the grant. Therefore, all funds were diverted to the purchase of tools, supplies, and other equipment necessary for the construction of vending machine prototypes. One advantage is that this increased opportunities for exploring the use of internet-enabled technologies in distance collaboration. RPI’s Generative Justice research team partnered with the Creativity Group, a social entrepreneurship organization affiliated with KNUST to establish a manufacturing facility. As of this writing, there is a corner of the Creativity Group’s maker space devoted to the vending machine production.

With our help Creativity Group purchased a 3D printer and a laser cutter to make gears, cams, and vending machine bodies. They have also purchased the requisite supplies (sheet metal, wood, plastic fibers, and pre-made coin mechanisms) to make about a dozen vending machines which they have used as sales samples, proof of concept demonstrations, and conference/expo presentations. 

During the purchase of manufacturing equipment, building the machines, and demonstrating the vending machines at expos several interviews were conducted by the co-PI over Skype and email. These interviews were crucial data points for the doctoral dissertation. The blueprints and instructions to build what we called an OSCVM RPI Mark 1 have been made available at https://github.com/OSCVM. Prior to the Github account these files were hosted at a WikMedia site that later had to be taken down due to excess spam that made the site unusable.

The intellectual merit of my dissertation included contributions to several ongoing conversations within Science and Technology Studies namely: critical making, technology’s role in development, and theoretical arguments surrounding the role of the researcher in political interventions.

The present literature on Critical Making says little about international collaborations and while prominent authors in the subfield have called for “opening up” universities’ facilities to the public, too few scholars had considered what the power dynamics of such an institutional arrangement might produce. My dissertation showed that while engaging with communities is productive for both parties, researchers must be careful to not establish relationships that make those communities more reliant on institutional support that cannot be assured long-term.

The dissertation’s contribution to development work was focused on the political economy of technological interventions. Contra existing work by Fisher and others that insist the developing world needs mass-manufactured tools, my work argues that a process that prioritizes sustainable manufacturing growth and geographically-situated tools that are context-aware, offer the most hope for equitable development.

Finally, my theoretical contribution used the real-time analysis of “the mangle” developed by Andrew Pickering to provide an emergent theory of capitalist production. This “sense-making tool” as I call it, helps to illuminate the social justice dimensions of technology design and production as it is happening, rather than applying predetermined categories. By putting the mangle in conversation with economic theories—in particular, assumptions that “efficiency” should take precedence over humanitarian considerations—the field may strengthen its positive program of prescriptive change and action.

The broader impacts of this research include a successful dissertation defense in July 2016, several presentations, and awards and recognition for the Creativity Group. On July 8, 2016 co-PI David Banks successfully defended his dissertation titled Three Theories of Praxis: Sense-Making Tools for Post-Capitalism where the NSF was credited as a funding source. A description of the project with photos is also available at the co-PI’s website at http://www.davidabanks.org/os-condom-vending-machine/.

Co-PI Ron Eglash presented data from this work during invited talks at the University of Virginia’s African and African American Studies Department; the Purdue Lectures in Ethics, Policy, and Science; the Cognizance Science Festival in Roorkee, India; and Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh.

Two students from the Creativity Group, Daniel Nomostu and Mathias Nyaka were selected from 3000 applicants across Africa to attend the 1st NO YAWA National Youth Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights Summit.  At MOBEX16, a digital economy conference, several models of the vending machine made with NSF funds was on display to show how mobile phone payments could be integrated into older kinds of technologies. The group also made Sustainia 2016’s list of 150 projects making impact across the world.
